name: Barahuco Canyon
description:
The upper part of the Río Barahuco is a limestone slot of crystalline water. It has been partially explored by some of the five or so canyoneers that live in the Dominican Republic. This has the potential to be the best known route in the DR.

The beta currently on this page was written from a bottom-up exploration to the bottom of the crux rappel, and then a conversation with Nicolas Bera, a Dominican canyoneer and one of only three people to have completed the route. For scouting to establish the full top-down route, satellite view shows a road just to the south of the drainage, running very close along the ridge. It would be a good place to scout from and/or fly a drone to see where to drop in. However, to start the canyon from this side would make for a long car shuttle, so the final approach route will likely start in the community to the north, and from there be less than a mile downhill to the canyon bottom.

You'll want a shorty wetsuit or more. Also, be careful of giant centipedes - these mountains seem to have more giant centipedes than anywhere in the DR, and indeed more than most tropical places, so keep your eyes open at all times - their bite is not dangerous but is extremely painful!

Approach

This approach is speculated. You'll want to drive up the steep dirt road trending northwest from the trail to Balneario La Plaza. Somewhere up here, north of the actually canyon, will be a place to park, and then a mostly downhill approach through mostly farms to reach the canyon.

If you are an exploration-ready team (bolt kit, 4x4 cars, GPS, machete, Spanish-fluency), talk to locals about where you can camp, and where the trail is. Apparently there IS a trail that farmers use. It's not on any map - yet.

You'll need two 4x4 vehicles with high clearance (would recommend beefy Jeep wranglers) for the shuttle. The gravel on the road is slippery and rental high clearance vehicles in 2023 spun wheels trying to go up (in fact one got a flat tire), so we returned to Estancia Don Armando (the parking area for Cañon de la Virgen), left our two vehicles there, and walked back. The road is not immediately visible on satellite maps, but it does exist, and had upgrades in 2022-2023. The author of this page has NOT driven if, so the shuttle route on the GPS track is estimated. But, it absolutely does exist.

You NEED to get help from a local guy who knows the area, and has down the canyon himself. Please call/text Jorgito Mendez (829) 691-9796, or just ask the local people where to find him. Jorgito is your best (and only?) bet for finding out the approach details.

Descent

From the estimated start point on this page, the canyon slowly slots up, with multiple rappels. In the beginning, flow is likely low, with no water hazards.

Nicolas says the route may need bolts replaced, as the bolts (and natural anchors) they used may corrode unpredictably in the mineral-rich water. Go prepared with a bolt kit and lots of webbing/rapides.

The biggest rappel in this upper part is probably 50m, down a trickling, sloping waterfall.

The canyon reaches its crux waterfall is almost total blackness (headlight mandatory) after passing multiple seeps in the walls where the flow pick up. Even in the height of the dry season, this waterfall is a thundering obstacle with no easy way down.

The author here only upclimbed to the base of the waterfall, but it appears around 20m in height, shooting off a narrow slot at an angle, and into a pitch-black pool with potential hydraulic hazards. Nicolas could not remember the specific details of how his first descent team passed this waterfall, but didn't remember it being as bad as it sounds. Regardless, be prepared to place multiple bolts to rappel out and possibly redirect away from the torrent. For this reason, the canyon's estimated rating is 'R' for hazard.

After the cruz waterfall, the flow actually drops slightly, as flow is lost into underground seeps. The canyon climaxes in beauty for an hour, continuing in darkness before emerging into sunlight. The jumps, slides and downclimbs in this section are the best of the best in the world. In a lifetime of canyoneering, in dozens of seasons of slots, this hallway will likely be one of the highlights of your life.

The slot gets slightly wider, enough that it is bright and sunny at noon. There is also green moss on the walls. The beauty is surreal.

{{

pic|lookingdowncanyon.jpg ~ Hereward Cooper in the canyon}}

There's one rappel here, in sunlight, with a set of bolts on the left. These bolts were placed by Hereward Cooper in January 2023, and, again, the mineral content may act unpredictably on them in the years to come. Be cautious.

All too soon, the slot brings you to an intersection where the canyon goes left and opens greatly. It's more a stream than a slot 15 minutes later when you reach the graffiti and trash-strewn Balneario La Plaza. Now time to exit.

Exit

The exit is a trail from Balneario La Plaza back to your shuttle car. This trail is easy to follow, and crosses the stream many times. It's never more than a few meters from the stream, until the end, where it goes uphill on stream-left for a few minutes to get back to your shuttle car.

Red tape

You are free to enter these mountains without a guide. Locals may tell you otherwise, but in general are very friendly and happy to see you coming. When you park at one of the houses, be sure you give a few hundred pesos to a family to watch your vehicle. Parking away from a house gives an opportunity for a break-in, which has happened before.

Background

This route was probably first descended by Nicolas Bera and team in 2021 or so. They descended it once, spending something likely 18 hours on the route due to having to bolt. They took down a local 60-year old man, who had never canyoneered before, and he apparently did fine.

They went through the second half of the canyon in total blackness. Nicolas states he remembers the route being good, but couldn't remember many specifics.

A group of American canyoneers (Michelle Niles, Hereward Cooper, Dan Kinler, Sarah Jorgenson, Lukas Eddy and Suhei Eddy) returned in January 2023 with almost no beta, and explored from the bottom up. They were unable to complete the route from the top down, as the exact drop-in point remains unmapped, and could require a fair bit of wandering around.

The next group needs a 4x4 vehicle, and a few days to park up at the top and look for the best approach route and drop-in point, and then to put it on the map.
